I found this game to be a bit odd compared to the others. It seemed like a Alex and Gordon Fan-Fic crossed with a Half-Life game. Regardless of this I still enjoyed the game and think it is a good Half-Life game.

Plot Spoiler:
[spoiler] I feel like killing Alex and bringing her back to life was kind of a weird thing to do and for whatever reason I do not really like it as it seems a bit too much. What I mean by this is it feels like it gives the Vorts a new ability which I think was unnecessary, but I did like the bit it led to with Gman so I forgive it. That being said I wonder if her dad will be brought back in the same way, whenever the next game comes out? I wish I had got to hear more of what he had to say. Also excited for the Borialis!!!! [/spoiler]

BUENARDISIMO

In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#373 out of 612)... it's time for Half-Life 2: Episode Two,

I remain baffled by Valve's expectation that anyone would want to jump into an episodic game series that they never bothered to finish, but I suppose that so many people are willing to do so speaks to the incredible appeal and profound resilience of the Half Life brand. I find myself somewhat... less willing to jump on board with this nonsense.

The long and short of it is that Valve really kind of sucks at storytelling. Sure, the settings they create are pretty damned fun to mess around in, but at this point it's pretty infuriating that they insist on ending every Half Life game with a cliffhanger. Let's just all suck it up and face reality here: there is zero indication that Valve has any concrete plans to continue, let alone conclude the Half Life story. I'm certain Episode Two here's level design and gunplay is as compelling and satisfying as you'd expect out of a Half Life game, but as what may-as-well be the chorus for this Impossible Quest of mine, I need more than just solid mechanics in my games. I need, in a word, context. A reason to care. Something to imbue the action with meaning. Simply knowing that Half Life 2: Episode 2 fails to conclude anything utterly saps my desire to play it.

Episodic games are pretty trendy these days, I'll admit. Well, maybe less so recently, but clearly it's a format that'll be around for a good while to come. But if a developer like Valve can't be bothered to finish their episodic game, with far greater resources than anyone else in the industry, then there can be no greater example than Episode Two of why you should never, ever, never buy an episodic game before the entire sequence has been released.
